words.def: A British signalling scheme designed to ensure the safe operation of a railway by allowing only one train to occupy a defined section of track (block) at a time[2]
words.name: Absolute block signalling

words.def: The most common type of railway, where power is applied by driving some or all of the wheels of the locomotive[3]
words.name: Adhesion railway

words.def: The weight on the driving wheels of a locomotive, which determines the frictional grip between wheels and rail, and hence the drawbar pull which a locomotive can exert[4]
words.name: Adhesive weight

words.def: A power braking system with compressed air as the operating medium[5]
words.name: Air brake

words.def: Similar to the dead man's switch other than it does not require the operator's constant interaction. Instead, an alarm is sounded at a preset interval in which the operator must respond by pressing a button to reset the alarm and timer if no other controls are operated. If the operator does not respond within a preset time, the prime mover is automatically throttled back to idle and the brakes are automatically applied.[6]
words.name: Alerter or watchdog

words.def: The adhesion available during traction mode with 99% reliability in all weather conditions[7]
words.name: All weather adhesion

words.def: An electrical generator that converts mechanical energy to electrical energy in the form of alternating current[8]
words.name: Alternator

words.def: The second largest builder of steam locomotives in the United States[9][10]
words.name: American Locomotive Company (ALCO)

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 4-4-0 wheel arrangement[11]
words.name: American type

words.def: A valve affixed to each end of a piece of rolling stock that, when opened, admits compressed air to the brake pipe (or vents it to the atmosphere if air hose is detached)[12]
words.name: Angle cock

words.def: Tubes connected to the water-space of the boiler provided in and across the firebox in order to add extra high-temperature heating surface. They also serve to support the brick arch or equivalent.[citation needed]
words.name: Arch tubes

words.def: A steam locomotive with one or more engine units that can move relative to the main frame[9][13]
words.name: Articulated locomotive

words.def: The sharing of one truck by adjacent ends of two rail vehicles
words.name: Articulation

words.def: A feature of a locomotive which has the same form and purpose as the domestic variety (i.e. to collect the ashes which fall through the bars of the grate). The only significant difference is the size, measured in feet rather than inches.
words.name: Ashpan

words.def: An alternating current electric motor whose speed varies with load and has no fixed relation to the frequency of the supply
words.name: Asynchronous

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 4-4-2 wheel arrangement[14][15][16]
words.name: Atlantic type

words.def: A system that consists of a series of signals that divide a railway line into a series of blocks and then functions to control the movement of trains between them through automatic signals
words.name: Automatic block signaling (ABS)

words.def: A general class of train protection systems for railways that involves a speed control mechanism in response to external inputs
words.name: Automatic train control (ATC)

words.def: An operational safety enhancement device used to help automate operations of trains
words.name: Automatic train operation (ATO)

words.def: Either of two implementations of a train protection system installed in some trains in order to help prevent collisions through a driver's failure to observe a signal or speed restriction
words.name: Automatic train protection (ATP)

words.def: A branch-line train consisting of a steam locomotive and passenger carriages that can be driven from either end by means of rodding to the regulator and an additional vacuum brake valve. The fireman remains with the locomotive and, when the driver is at the other end, the fireman controls the cut off and vacuum ejectors in addition to his usual duties.
words.name: Autotrain, push-pull train

words.def:
The housing that holds the axle bearings of a locomotive[17]
The housing attaching the end of the axle to the bogie which contains the bearing allowing the axle to rotate.[18] See also journal box below.
words.name: Axlebox or axle box

words.def: A tag or note applied to a defective piece of equipment. Generally, equipment tagged as bad order is not to be used until repairs are performed and the equipment is inspected and approved for use.[19][20]
words.name: Bad order

words.def: To release the locomotive brakes while the train brakes are being applied in order to permit smoother handling and prevent excessive slack, wheel slide and flat wheels[21]
words.name: Bail off

words.def: The reciprocation and revolving masses of any steam, diesel or electric locomotive need balancing, if it is to work smoothly. Revolving masses can easily be balanced by counterweights, but the balancing of reciprocating parts is a matter of compromise and judgement.
words.name: Balancing

words.def: Aggregate stone, gravel, or cinders forming the track bed on which sleepers (ties) and track are laid to ensure stability and proper drainage[19][22]
words.name: Ballast

words.def: See Tamping machine.
words.name: Ballast tamper

words.def: A looped length of track, usually at the end of a spur or branch, which allows trains to turn around for the return trip without reversing or shunting. Can be used as part of a freight installation to allow the loading or unloading of bulk materials without the need to stop the train (see merry-go-round train (MGR)).
words.name: Balloon

words.def: A platform and track arrangement where the train pulls into a siding, or dead-end, when serving the platform
words.name: Bay platform

words.def: A one-of-a-kind switcher locomotive (also referred to as the SWBLW) built by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway in 1970
words.name: Beep

words.def: A widening of an underground rail tunnel, in preparation for future connection or expansion of service. Used particularly in subway nomenclature.[23][24]
words.name: Bellmouth

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-8-4 wheel arrangement[25][26][27]
words.name: Berkshire type

words.def: A part of a steam locomotive that discharges exhaust steam from the cylinders into the smokebox beneath the chimney in order to increase the draught through the fire
words.name: Blastpipe

words.def: A locomotive with a four-wheel per truck configuration, each individually powered, as opposed to a six-wheel "Co-Co" configuration.
words.name: Bo-Bo (Europe)

words.def: A cylindrical container adjacent to the firebox in which steam is produced to drive a steam locomotive[28]
words.name: Boiler

words.def: A transverse floating beam member of truck suspension system supporting the weight of vehicle body[29]
words.name: Bolster

words.def: A barrier at a level crossings
words.name: Boom barrier

words.def: An extra set of cylinders that can be engaged on a steam locomotive to drive a trailing truck or tender truck to give additional tractive effort at starting and low speeds[19][30]
words.name: Booster engine

words.def: A small hut at one end of a railway wagon to protect the brakeman from the elements
words.name: Brakeman's cabin or brakeman's cab

words.def: The main air pipe of a train's air brake system[31]
words.name: Brake pipe

words.def: A secondary railway line that splits off from a main line[19]
words.name: Branch line

words.def: A brick or concrete baffle provided at the front of a locomotive firebox below the tubes, in order to extend the flame path. Early locomotives burned coke; provision of a brick arch was necessary before coal could be used without producing excessive smoke.
words.name: Brick arch

words.def: A type of platform trolley found on stations all over the UK rail network from the late 1960s to the early 1980s
words.name: British Rail Universal Trolley Equipment (BRUTE)

words.def: Track where the rails are spaced more widely apart than 1,435 mm (4 ft 8 1⁄2 in) (which is called standard gauge).[19] Many early railroads were broad gauge, for example the Great Western Railway in the UK which adopted 7 ft (2,134 mm) gauge until it was converted to standard gauge in the 1860s - 1890s. Russia still has over 80,000 km (50,000 mi) of broad gauge (1,520 mm (4 ft 11 27⁄32 in)) railroads. Broad gauge is also normal in Spain and Portugal (1,668 mm (5 ft 5 21⁄32 in) Iberian gauge), in India (1,676 mm (5 ft 6 in) Indian gauge), as well as Ireland and used in some parts of Australia (1,600 mm (5 ft 3 in) Irish gauge).
words.name: Broad gauge

words.def: A British Rail Class 121 railcar[32]
words.name: Bubble car

words.def: A side operated version of the top or bottom operated Janney coupler[33]
words.name: Buckeye coupler

words.def: A device that cushions the impact of rail vehicles against each other
words.name: Buffer

words.def: The barrier installed at the end of a dead-end track to prevent rail vehicles from proceeding further
words.name: Buffer stop or bumper post

words.def: The nameplate on locomotives and rolling stock
words.name: Builder's plate

words.def: An open-top flatcar with a wall at each end
words.name: Bulkhead flatcar

words.def: The housing for signals and communications computers that control switches, crossings, and other such controls, relaying information to and from the RTC (rail traffic control)[34]
words.name: Bungalow

words.def: The practice of replacing train service, whether light rail, tram/streetcar systems, or full-size railway systems, with a bus service, either on a temporary or permanent basis. Somewhat derogatory and mainly used in the UK, Canada, USA, and Australia. The word is a portmanteau of the words "bus" and "substitution".
words.name: Bustitution

words.def: The control room of a locomotive housing the engine crew and their control consoles[35][36]
words.name: Cab

words.def: A steam locomotive with its cab at the leading end of the boiler, rather than the usual trailing end adjacent to the tender. The best known example is the Southern Pacific Railroad's AC type, built to handle drag freights through the SP's many tunnels and snow sheds without the danger of the exhaust asphyxiating the engine crew.
words.name: Cab forward

words.def: A locomotive without a cab. Commonly referred to as a B unit or a Slug, although not all Slugs are cabless.
words.name: Cabless

words.def: A railroad car attached usually to the end of a train, in which railroad workers could ride and monitor track and rolling stock conditions. Largely obsolete, having been replaced by the electronic end-of-train device (ETD), or flashing rear-end device (FRED).[37]
words.name: Caboose

words.def: The angle of an individual rail relative to vertical (e.g. around curves)
words.name: Cant

words.def: A locomotive which derives its structural strength from a bridge-truss design framework in the sides and roof, which cover the full width of the locomotive
words.name: Carbody unit

words.def: The overhead wire system used to send electricity to an electric locomotive or multiple unit, tram or light rail vehicle[37]
words.name: Catenary

words.def: A bulkhead flatcar with a braced beam bisecting its length, used to transport lumber products
words.name: Centerbeam

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 4-6-6-4 wheel arrangement[38][39][40][41]
words.name: Challenger type

words.def: A heavier duty locomotive with six wheels per bogie (all axles being separately driven) configuration as opposed to a four-wheel "Bo-Bo" configuration. The correct classification is Co'Co', but Co-Co is used more often.
words.name: Co-Co (EU)

words.def: A steam-operated device in the tender intended to push coal forward to a point where it can be shovelled directly into the fire[42]
words.name: Coal pusher

words.def: A signal in which the colour of the light determines the meaning of the aspect shown
words.name: Colour light signal

words.def: A signaling system that uses both colour and light position to determine the meaning of the aspect shown
words.name: Colour position signal

words.def: A handle or lever which controls both the throttle and the dynamic braking on the locomotive: on a desktop-type control stand, forward (away from operator) past center operates the dynamic brake, backward (toward operator), past center, is throttle up[43][44][45]
words.name: Combined power handle

words.def: A steam locomotive passing steam through two sets of cylinders. One set uses high pressure steam, then passes the low pressure exhausted steam to the second.[46]
words.name: Compound locomotive

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-8-0 wheel arrangement[47][48]
words.name: Consolidation type

words.def: The loading of a shipping container onto a simple flat car[37]
words.name: Container on flat car (COFC)

words.def: A form of track in which the rails are welded together by utilising the thermite reaction or flash butt welding to form one continuous rail that may be several kilometres long[37]
words.name: Continuous welded rail (CWR)

words.def: A passenger coach which has a full set of train controls at one end, allowing for the use of push-pull train operation[49]
words.name: Control car

words.def: Effective length of piece of rolling stock
words.name: Coupler pulling faces, length over

words.def: Rods between crank pins on the wheels, transferring power from a driving axle to a driven axle of a locomotive[50]
words.name: Coupling rods

words.def: A type of rolling stock with a flat bottom enclosed on all sides and top, which is loaded and unloaded from sliding doors on each side[19][51]
words.name: Covered goods wagon (UIC)

words.def: A diesel locomotive with a crew cab permanently coupled to and acting as a controller for a similar slave diesel locomotive without a crew cab, primarily used for switching/shunting duties for large groups of rolling stock. Also known as master and slave, as in the British Rail Class 13 shunters at Tinsley Marshalling Yard.
words.name: Cow-calf or cow and calf

words.def: A pin protruding from a wheel into a main or coupling rod
words.name: Crank pin

words.def: In a steam locomotive, the moving member of a sliding guide which absorbs upward and downward forces from the connecting (main) rod, which otherwise would tend to bend the piston rod[52]
words.name: Crosshead

words.def:
To uncouple one or more cars from a train (i.e. to "make a cut")[53]
Same as "cutting"[53]
words.name: Cut

words.def: A manual lever which releases the pin of an automatic coupler when pulled to separate cars or locomotives[54][55]
words.name: Cut lever

words.def: A variable device on steam locomotives which closes the steam valve to the steam cylinder before the end of the piston stroke, thus conserving steam while allowing the steam in the cylinder to expand under its own energy. See also: Reverser handle.
words.name: Cut off

words.def: A channel dug through a hillside to enable rail track to maintain a shallow gradient. See also embankment.
words.name: Cutting

words.def: Making repeated service brake reductions in short succession to maintain a constant speed on short but steep grades. Each reduction must be at least 5 PSI lower than the previous one in order to keep the brakes applying regularly, but excessive cycle braking can deplete the air supply and require an emergency application.[56]
words.name: Cycle braking

words.def: A cavity in a reciprocating engine in which a piston travels
words.name: Cylinder

words.def: On steam locomotives, this appurtenance allows condensed water to be drained from the steam cylinders when the throttle is opened, thus preventing damage to the pistons, running gear, and cylinder heads[57]
words.name: Cylinder cock

words.def: A block signal that is displaying no discernible aspect, often due to burned out lamps or local power failure. Most railroads require that a dark signal be treated as displaying its most restrictive aspect (e.g. stop and stay for an absolute signal).[58]
words.name: Dark signal

words.def: A section of track without block signals[59]
words.name: Dark territory

words.def: A safety mechanism on a train controller which automatically applies the brake if a lever is released. It is intended to stop a train if the driver is incapacitated. In some forms, this device may be pedal-actuated. See also Dead-man's vigilance device.
words.name: Dead man's handle

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-10-0 wheel arrangement[60][61][62]
words.name: Decapod type

words.def: A track side device used to detect various defects such as hotboxes (overheated axle bearings), dragging equipment, leaning cars, overloaded cars, overheight cars, seized (locked) wheels, etc.[63]
words.name: Defect detector

words.def: A monetary charge levied by a railroad to a customer for excessive delay in loading or unloading cars
words.name: Demurrage

words.def: A safety device that will derail vehicles passing it, often used to prevent rolling stock from unintentionally entering the mainline from a siding[63]
words.name: Derail or derailer

words.def: Small explosive charges placed on the running rail which detonate when run over—used to warn drivers in following trains of an incident ahead
words.name: Detonator

words.def: Track which allows a rail line to cross another at grade[63]
words.name: Diamond

words.def: A set of diesel-powered self-propelling passenger rail vehicles able to operate in multiple with other such sets. Such units, especially those consisting of a single vehicle, are sometimes termed railcars.
words.name: Diesel multiple unit (DMU)

words.def: A system in which train dispatchers communicate directly with train crews via radio to authorize track occupancy in predefined blocks[63]
words.name: Direct traffic control (DTC)

words.def: A practice employed to move large trains through the mountains. Consists of the locomotives on the head end, a "swing" (mid-train) helper or two, and pusher locomotive(s) on the rear; today, all units are remotely controlled by the engineer in the lead unit. The power distribution alleviates stress on the couplers and relieves the lead units of the full weight of the train, making it easier to move on grades.
words.name: Distributed power

words.def: A pair of lights, usually found on modern locomotives, located several feet below and outboard of the main headlight, that may alternately flash when the train is sounding its horn[64]
words.name: Ditch lights

words.def: The trackage area under the jurisdiction of a railway superintendent[65]
words.name: Division

words.def: A spike with a slightly altered head shape for easier extraction when the spike has become too loose in the sleeper[66][67]
words.name: Dog or dogspike (India)

words.def: A self-powered gasoline-electric passenger car used for small capacity rural commuter service.[63] Also a British Rail Class 153 DMU.
words.name: Doodlebug

words.def: If a train has insufficient power to climb a grade and no helpers are available, the train will be split into two sections and run separately to the top.[68]
words.name: Double

words.def: A configuration in which two steam locomotives are coupled head-to-tail in order to haul a heavy train up a long or steep hill. In the present day, double heading (and occasionally triple heading) are done primarily on large passenger trains or as a show for railfans.
words.name: Double heading

words.def: A long, heavy freight train moving at low speed
words.name: Drag

words.def: See Defect detector.[63]
words.name: Dragging equipment detector

words.def: The part of a coupler that attaches to the frame of the car or locomotive; may be equipped with a pneumatic cushion depending on a freight car's design cargo (e.g. an autorack). Alternately, the pinned double bars coupling a steam locomotive to its tender.
words.name: Drawbar

words.def: The operator of a locomotive[69]
words.name: Driver or engine driver

words.def: Operation of a train by the engineer or driver only.[70] Also known as one person train operation (OPTO)
words.name: Driver only operation (DO or DOO)

words.def: A wheel in contact with the rail that also propels a locomotive
words.name: Driver

words.def: A signal light that is considerably smaller and closer to the ground than a high-mast signal; often absolute, and placed within interlocking limits, its aspects tend to differ from those conveyed by a taller signal for certain indications. Also called 'pot' or 'jack'.
words.name: Dwarf signal

words.def: The use of a traction motors' output, working as generators, to retard train speed without relying solely on the air brakes
words.name: Dynamic braking

words.def:
A component of vacuum brake system usually fitted in pairs. Steam passing through a cone sucks air from the train pipe to create the vacuum.
A small ejector running continuously to overcome leaks and to restore the vacuum after light braking and a large ejector operated when needed to release the brakes quickly after a heavy application or to create the initial vacuum after coupling
words.name: Ejector

words.def: A set of electrically powered self-propelling passenger rail vehicles able to operate in multiple with other such sets
words.name: Electric multiple unit (EMU)

words.def: The world's second largest builder of railroad locomotives. EMD was previously Electro-Motive Division of General Motors before being sold.
words.name: Electro-Motive Diesel (EMD)

words.def: A railway built on supports over city streets
words.name: Elevated railway, el, or L

words.def: A bank, usually of earth but sometimes of stone, constructed to form a level or minimally graded trackbed for a line of railway needing to pass over a depression in the terrain or other pre-existing surface feature. See also cutting.
words.name: Embankment

words.def: A train used to bring carriages into (or out of) service. They usually run between sidings and main stations, with the carriages then forming a service train to another destination. They are often worked under freight train rules (e.g. without needing a guard in the UK).[71]
words.name: Empty coaching stock (ECS)

words.def: A switching locomotive with no short hood, thus having its cab forming one end of its carbody
words.name: End-cab switcher

words.def: A small air reservoir in a locomotive control stand. When the automatic brake valve is operated, this reservoir responds by reducing or increasing the air pressure in the brake pipe.[72]
words.name: Equalizing reservoir

words.def: A device that continuously captures analog and digital train systems information and stores that data for a minimum of 48 hours. This data is used to evaluate incidents and accidents. Typical stored data includes speed, brake pressure, dynamic brake, horn activation, track signal, etc. In the U.S., event recorders are mandated by the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) for freight, passenger and commuter rail. Regulations for railroad outside the U.S. vary by country. Transit operations are not generally required to have event recorders, but have begun to add them voluntarily.
words.name: Event recorder

words.def: A train that passes selected stations without stopping
words.name: Express train

words.def: A train not included in the normal schedule of a railroad[73][74][75] They often run during busy holiday travel periods in order to handle larger crowds and reduce the number of passengers that are forced to stand or are stranded at a station. In train order territory, extras are required to clear the main line for scheduled trains to pass.[76]
words.name: Extra

words.def: A turnout that can select which way to diverge a train—the opposite of trailing
words.name: Facing

words.def: A type of articulated locomotive, typically (but not exclusively) with two boilers and connected fireboxes in a central cab
words.name: Fairlie

words.def: A heavy, hinged steel plate attached in a horizontal position to the rear of the locomotive footplate or front of a locomotive tender. When the tender is attached to its locomotive the plate is allowed to fall to cover the gap in the "floor" between the two units. The sliding edge is not fixed and has a smooth chamfer so as to avoid a trip hazard.[77]
words.name: Fall plate

words.def: A device to preheat the water for a steam locomotive to improve efficiency
words.name: Feedwater heater

words.def: A valve which controls the amount of air pressure being channelled from the locomotive's main reservoir to the brake pipe, in accordance with the set pressure in the equalizing reservoir[78]
words.name: Feed valve or regulating valve

words.def: A concealed group of sidings used in model railways to provide more realistic operation in limited space
words.name: Fiddle yard

words.def: In steam railroading, a chamber in which a fire would produce sufficient heat to create steam once the hot gases from the firebox were carried into the adjacent boiler via tubes or flues[79]
words.name: Firebox

words.def: A worker whose primary job is to shovel coal into the firebox and ensure that the boiler maintains sufficient steam pressure
words.name: Fireman, stoker, or boilerman

words.def: A wheel defect where the tread of a wheel has a flat spot and is no longer round; flats can be heard as regular clicking or banging noises when the wheel passes by. This is caused either by a locked bearing, or a brake that was not fully released before the car was moved, dragging the wheel without turning.[80]
words.name: Flat

words.def: A railway junction that has a track configuration in which merging or crossing railroad lines provide track connections with each other without requiring trains to cross over in front of opposing traffic[80]
words.name: Flying junction or flyover

words.def: The point of a switch turnout where a car or locomotive on one track will obstruct movement on the adjacent track[81]
words.name: Fouling point

words.def: The area between the running rails of a standard gauge track. The actual distance between the rails is 4 ft 8 1⁄2 in (1,435 mm). See also six-foot and ten-foot.[82]
words.name: Four-foot

words.def: A type of boom barrier
words.name: Four-quadrant gate

words.def: A type of modular layout in model railroading
words.name: Free-mo

words.def: A car designed to transport freight
words.name: Freight wagon (UIC)

words.def: The maximum air pressure that can be exerted against brake pistons in a normal brake application. To increase pressure beyond this point, the brakes must be placed in emergency.[83]
words.name: Full service reduction

words.def: A pyrotechnic device similar to an automotive flare that is used for signalling[80]
words.name: Fusee

words.def: A threaded plug, with a soft metal core, that is screwed into the crown plate of a firebox. If the water level gets too low the core melts and the noise of the escaping steam warns the enginemen.
words.name: Fusible plug

words.def: A type of steam locomotive that is articulated into three parts[84]
words.name: Garratt

words.def: The width between the inner faces of the rails
words.name: Gauge

words.def: Any of the GP ("general-purpose") series of Electro-Motive four-axle diesel locomotives; originally applied only to EMD GP7, GP9, and GP18 models[85]
words.name: Geep

words.def: The control switch of a diesel-electric locomotive that opens or closes the circuit between the main generator and the traction motors[86]
words.name: Generator field

words.def: To break a train in two, usually by shearing the knuckle pin in a coupler, often caused by the application of excessive head end power at startup[87][88]
words.name: Get a knuckle

words.def: A nickname for General Electric's Evolution series of modern diesel locomotives[89][90]
words.name: GEVO

words.def: A quick coupling and uncoupling connector at the end of a trainline air hose that resembles a pair of shaking hands when hoses are connected
words.name: Gladhand connector

words.def: A hand-powered railroad car (see Handcar and Draisine), or a small gasoline powered railroad car[91][92]
words.name: Go-devil

words.def: A handle on the side of a car to allow switching personnel to hold on[93]
words.name: Grab bar or grab iron

words.def: A colour associated with go or proceed
words.name: Green

words.def: The condition of locomotives and cars swaying in opposite directions when traversing depressions on the roadbed. A potentially dangerous condition that can cause coupler damage, lading damage, or derailments at slower speeds.[94][95]
words.name: Harmonic rock or harmonic rock and roll

words.def: A scheme whereby the locomotive engine or a separate generator provides hotel power to carriages[96]
words.name: Head-end power (HEP)

words.def: A sign attached to a locomotive to identify a named train or charter, or for other special occasions[97]
words.name: Headboard

words.def: A transverse structural member located at the extreme end of a rail vehicle's underframe. The headstock supports the coupling at that end of the vehicle, and may also support buffers, in which case it may also be known as a "buffer beam".[98]
words.name: Headstock

words.def: Heavy freight operations[99][100][101]
words.name: Heavy haul

words.def: The upper rail in a curve or superelevation which typically experiences the higher lateral loads and greater wear
words.name: High rail

words.def: A passing siding. Inferior trains "lay over in the hole" to let superior ones pass.[102]
words.name: Hole

words.def: See absolute signal.
words.name: Home signal

words.def: Plates lining the axlebox cut-outs in a locomotive frame to allow smooth vertical movement under control of the springs[103][104]
words.name: Horn blocks

words.def: The action of shuttling a locomotive from the yard to the engine house or vice versa[105]
words.name: Hostling

words.def: An axle bearing that has become excessively hot due to friction[96][106][107]
words.name: Hotbox

words.def: A device attached to the track which monitors passing trains for hot axles, and then reports the results via a radio transmission (typical in the US) or a circuit to the signal box (typical in the UK). See defect detector.[96]
words.name: Hotbox detector

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 4-6-4 wheel arrangement[27][108]
words.name: Hudson type

words.def: A raised section in a rail sorting yard that allows operators to use gravity to move freight railcars into the proper position within the yard when making up trains of cars. This is faster and requires less effort than moving cars with a switching engine.[96]
words.name: Hump

words.def: Swaying motion of a railway vehicle or bogie caused by the coning action on which the directional stability of an adhesion railway depends. The truck or bogie wanders from side to side between the rails, "hunting" for the optimum location based on the forces at play.[96]
words.name: Hunting

words.def: The braking system that applies or releases the brakes of a locomotive independently from its train[109][110]
words.name: Independent brake or locomotive brake

words.def: A train station built on an existing passenger line to address demand in a location between existing stations
words.name: Infill station or in-fill station

words.def: A device to force water into a steam locomotive's boiler by steam pressure[111]
words.name: Injector

words.def: Rail joints incorporating insulation to isolate individual track circuits[112][113]
words.name: Insulated rail joint (IRJ) or insulated block joint (IBJ)

words.def: Any track or yard where rail cars are transferred from one carrier to another[114][115]
words.name: Interchange

words.def: Moving goods by more than one type of vehicle. Intermodal freight can be transported using shipping containers which can easily be transferred among railroad flatcars, ships, airplanes, and tractor-trailer trucks.[111]
words.name: Intermodal freight

words.def: Moving people by more than one type of vehicle[111]
words.name: Intermodal passenger

words.def: A railway platform that has tracks along the full lengths of both sides
words.name: Island platform

words.def: A metal plate that joins the ends of rails in jointed track[116]
words.name: Joint bar or rail joiner

words.def: Track in which the rails are laid in lengths of around 20 m and bolted to each other end-to-end by means of fishplates or joint bars[117]
words.name: Jointed track

words.def: A bearing without rolling elements; a plain bearing[118]
words.name: Journal bearing

words.def: The housing of a journal bearing[118][119]
words.name: Journal box

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 4-4-4 wheel arrangement[120]
words.name: Jubilee type

words.def: A point at which two lines or separate routes diverge from each other[117]
words.name: Junction

words.def: A padlock or hook securing the lever of a hand-operated switch, thereby preventing the switch points from moving as rolling stock passes over them[121][122]
words.name: Keeper

words.def: To shove a car a short distance and uncouple it in motion, allowing it to roll free under gravity and/or its own inertia onto a track. Commonly practiced in bowl or hump yards to make up or break down trains or classify large numbers of cars in an expedient fashion. Differs from a flying switch in that the locomotive is pushing the car rather than pulling it when the cut is made.[123]
words.name: Kick

words.def: A freight car with a defect in its brake valve that causes the entire train's brake system to go into emergency when any application is made[124]
words.name: Kicker

words.def: The outline of the space beside and above the track that must be kept clear of obstructions for the train to pass. This can be larger than the static clearance around an unmoving engine or car.[125] See also: loading gauge and structure gauge
words.name: Kinematic envelope (KE)

words.def: The articulating part of a coupler that locks automatically in its closed position to join rail cars; so named because its movement resembles that of the human finger[126]
words.name: Knuckle

words.def: A non-main track from which several others branch within a short distance, such as within a rail yard or engine terminal[127]
words.name: Lead track

words.def: A crossing on one level ("at-grade intersection")—without recourse to a bridge or tunnel—generally of a railway line by a road or path
words.name: Level crossing, railroad crossing, railway crossing, train crossing, or grade crossing

words.def: A locomotive travelling on its own, or perhaps with just a caboose (brake van) attached[128]
words.name: Light engine

words.def: A city-based rail system based on tram design standards that operates mostly in private rights-of-way separated from other traffic but sometimes, if necessary, mixed with other traffic in city streets.[129] Light rail vehicles (LRV) generally have a top speed of around 55 mph (89 km/h) though mostly operating at much lower speeds, more akin to road vehicles. Light rail vehicles usually run on trackage that weighs less per foot (due to a smaller track profile) than the tracks used for main-line freight trains; thus they are "light rail" due to the smaller rails usually used.[128]
words.name: Light rail

words.def: An obsolete method of coupling rail cars, consisting of manually dropping the coupling pin into the drawbar as the cars joined. Extremely hazardous to the brakemen of its day, it was outlawed in the United States by the Railroad Safety Appliance Act of 1893.
words.name: Link and pin

words.def: A train that stops at most, if not all, stations along its route.[130] Often referred to in North America as a "milk train" or "milk run" (usage from the days when trains stopped at every station and stop along their route to pick up fresh milk brought to the stations daily from local dairy farms).[131][132][133]
words.name: Local train

words.def: An off-white color of railway signal light, like the Moon, achieved by the use of a clear lens of very light blue, to make it distinct from a light that has a broken lens.[134][135] In UK practice, it is the color used for the type of junction indicator known as a feather, so-called for its resemblance to a popular inn sign.[citation needed]
words.name: Lunar

words.def: The electric generator in a diesel-electric locomotive that is coupled directly to the prime mover and feeds electrical energy to the traction motors[136]
words.name: Main generator

words.def: The compressed-air tank of a locomotive containing source air for the brakes and other pneumatic appliances[137]
words.name: Main reservoir

words.def: A type of articulated locomotive designed by Anatole Mallet.[138][139] See Compound engine.
words.name: Mallet (pronounced "mallay")

words.def: An express freight train carrying a variety of general merchandise[140][141]
words.name: Manifest

words.def: A signal in which the aspect is conveyed by moving an arm[142][143]
words.name: Mechanical semaphore signal

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-8-2 wheel arrangement[144]
words.name: Mikado type

words.def: A aggregator for transporting milk from farms to dairies, such as British Railways Milk Trains[133]
words.name: Milk train

words.def: An inter-modal car
words.name: Modalohr

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-6-0 wheel arrangement[145]
words.name: Mogul type

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 4-8-2 wheel arrangement[146]
words.name: Mountain type

words.def: The bottom of the water space surrounding a steam locomotive's firebox that collects solid deposits distilled from the water supply during the boiling process[147]
words.name: Mud ring

words.def: A system of colour-light signalling in which signals may show three or four aspects[148]
words.name: Multiple aspect signalling

words.def: A self-propelled rail vehicle that can be joined with compatible others and controlled from a single driving station. The sub-classes of this type of vehicle; Diesel Multiple Unit (DMU), Diesel-Electric Multiple Unit (DEMU) and Electric Multiple Unit (EMU) are more common terms. These may also be termed railcars.
words.name: Multiple unit (MU)

words.def: Railroad track where the rails are spaced less than 1,435 mm (4 ft 8 1⁄2 in) apart,[149] often found in mountainous terrain where the cost savings of building a smaller railroad can be considerable[citation needed]
words.name: Narrow gauge

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 4-8-4 wheel arrangement, also known in North America as "Pocono", "Niagara", "Confederation", "Greenbrier", and "Potomac"[150][151]
words.name: Northern type

words.def: The eighth notch of a locomotive throttle control, indicating full power[152][153]
words.name: Notch 8 or run 8

words.def: A form of freight hauling car for bulk goods[154]
words.name: Open wagon (UIC)

words.def: When equipment is placed ahead of the fouling point of a switch turnout
words.name: Out to foul

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 4-6-2 wheel arrangement[155]
words.name: Pacific type

words.def: A tank locomotive with the water tanks mounted on the boiler like panniers
words.name: Pannier tank

words.def: A linkage to pick up current from overhead lines[156][157]
words.name: Pantograph

words.def: Colloquially, a track warrant, train order or other movement permit that is dictated by a dispatcher and copied in writing by a train crew member[citation needed]
words.name: Paper

words.def:
Abbreviation for the former Pennsylvania Railroad[158]
A nickname for the PRR's K-4 class steam locomotive[citation needed]
words.name: Pennsy

words.def:
A fee paid by a rail company to the owner of a car (or wagon) for the time it spends on the company's property[156][159]
An authorized living expense payment for some workers forced away from their home terminal[156][160]
words.name: Per diem (pronounced by some U.S. railroaders per die-um, not per dee-um)

words.def: A block signal whose most restrictive indication is stop and proceed. A permissive signal is identified by the presence of a number plate affixed to the mast or supporting structure. Proceeding beyond a permissive signal at stop is allowed at restricted speed if operating conditions enable a train operator to stop before reaching any train or obstruction.[161][162][163]
words.name: Permissive signal

words.def:
A deflective shield affixed to the front of a locomotive to protect its wheels from on-track debris; archaically called a "cowcatcher"[164] See also: Pilot (locomotive)
An employee qualified on the operating rules and physical characteristics of a certain section of the railroad, assisting a crew who is not so qualified[165][166] See also: Railroad engineer
words.name: Pilot

words.def:
The leading locomotive during a double-heading operation[167]
An unattached locomotive driven a specified distance in front of a special train[167][168][169]
words.name: Pilot engine

words.def: Where it is necessary to temporarily work a section of line as single track (for instance if the other track of a double track line is out of use), a person (the pilot man) acts as the single track token.
words.name: Pilot man

words.def: The moving component in the cylinder of a steam engine or internal combustion engine that translates into motion the force exerted by pressurised steam or quickly-burning fuel[170]
words.name: Piston

words.def: A specified distance that a brake piston may move from its cylinder to the brake rigging. If the travel exceeds or falls short of this distance, the equipment must be set out for repair.[171]
words.name: Piston travel

words.def: A two-wheel truck or bogie at the front of a locomotive[172]
words.name: Pony truck

words.def: The extended walkway at either end of a U.S. locomotive[173]
words.name: Porch

words.def:
A largely antiquated job involving physical duties such as lifting. Various types of porter include:

A baggage porter assisted with luggage.
An operating porter assisted with safeworking duties.
A station porter assisted with general station duties.
A lad porter was a junior station porter.
words.name: Porter

words.def: The practice of coupling two or more passenger trains together over common sections of their respective routes, but otherwise operating the trains separately[174][175]
words.name: Portion working

words.def: A block signal in which the position of the lights determine the meaning of the aspect shown
words.name: Position light signal

words.def: A system of functional requirements for monitoring and controlling train movements to provide increased safety
words.name: Positive train control (PTC)

words.def: A period of time when one or more tracks are closed for maintenance. For the duration of work a person in charge of possession (PICOP) has control of the line. When work is complete the possession is relinquished and control of the line handed back to the signaller.[176]
words.name: Possession

words.def: The weight (and thus the cross section) of a length of rail. A heavier rail can carry heavier loads with less distortion and less damage to the rails themselves and the roadbed.
words.name: Pound

words.def: A locomotive or group of connected (MU'd) locomotives serving as the motive power for a train[156]
words.name: Power

words.def: Pulling against the train brakes at the higher end of the locomotive's power output (e.g. notches five through eight on a conventional throttle). This is considered wasteful of fuel and brake shoes, and is therefore discouraged by most operating departments.[177][178]
words.name: Power braking

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-6-2 wheel arrangement[179]
words.name: Prairie type

words.def: The internal combustion engine of a diesel locomotive
words.name: Prime mover

words.def: A rail broken from cold-related contraction[180][181]
words.name: Pull-apart

words.def: A pole about 12 feet (366 cm) long and having a diameter of 5 inches (127 mm). They were placed in receptacles called push pole pockets. The pole was placed between the locomotive and the freight car, and used to push the car on or off a siding or to another track. Used between 1870 and the mid-1960s.[182]
words.name: Push pole

words.def: A mode of operation whereby a locomotive-hauled train may be driven with the locomotive at the front, middle or back of the train. See also: Auto train. See Top and tail for train with locomotives at both front and back.[156]
words.name: Push–pull

words.def: A federally mandated safety inspection performed on a locomotive every 92 operating days[183]
words.name: Quarterly inspection or periodic inspection

words.def: A steep-grade railway with a toothed rack rail (usually between the running rails), used when adhesion is insufficient
words.name: Rack railway, rack-and-pinion railway, or cog railway

words.def: A passenger rail vehicle (typically non-articulated or rigid frame) that was derived from bus propulsion and construction technology, but which may evolve into larger dimensions, performance, and characteristics similar in appearance to a light DMU railcar
words.name: Railbus

words.def: A powered single unit or articulated passenger car, usually “railroad-derived” light DMU or EMU, with a driver's cab at one or both ends
words.name: Railcar

words.def: A hobbyist or enthusiast of trains
words.name: Railfan

words.def: A machine used to remove irregularities in the surface of the rails that may be self-powered or part of a consist
words.name: Rail grinder

words.def: The cross section shape of rail. There are many rail profiles which are often specific to individual railroads. Rails need to be periodically scanned electronically, the data inspected and analysed, then re-profiled with rail grinding machines to maintain the safe and proper "rail profile". Rails that cannot be brought back to the proper rail profile are condemned and replaced.
words.name: Rail profile

words.def: A screeching train-track friction sound, most commonly occurring on sharp curves or heavy braking[184]
words.name: Rail squeal

words.def: A small petrol (gas) or diesel shunting (switcher) locomotive
words.name: Rail tractor

words.def: Any railroad vehicle other than a locomotive
words.name: Railroad car

words.def: Artifacts of railways around the world
words.name: Railroadiana

words.def:
A railway route connecting two or more places or other railway routes[185]
A railway route constructed by an organization, usually one formed for that purpose[185][186][187]
A railway route which has been given the line name officially (e.g. by engineers line references in the UK)[188]
A set of railway routes which are bundled for publicity purposes (e.g. a UK train operating company)[189][190]
A set of railway routes without official standing, on which railfans have bestowed a title[citation needed]
words.name: Railway line

words.def: A train station, a stopping point for trains, usually with passenger access
words.name: Railway station

words.def: A building for passengers at the end of a railway line
words.name: Railway terminal

words.def: A colour generally associated with stop, when shown by signals or flags
words.name: Red

words.def: The area between, under, or within a few feet of cars and locomotives. To enter the zone, a ground employee must obtain protection from the locomotive engineer (if a locomotive is coupled) or a blue signal (if no locomotive is coupled).[191][192][193]
words.name: Red zone

words.def: A refrigerated railcar, used to transport perishable goods[194]
words.name: Reefer

words.def: A siding used as a passing place on a main line, where slow trains may be held whilst an express passes—a simpler, but less convenient, form of the passing loop
words.name: Refuge siding

words.def: A two- to four-letter code, assigned by the Association of American Railroads, that is applied to equipment operating on North American railroads to identify the owner[195][196][197]
words.name: Reporting mark

words.def: A metal casting slotted over the rail near the wheel of a derailed train car. The engine then pushes or pulls the car so that the derailed wheel runs up the rerailer and back onto the track.[198]
words.name: Rerail frog or rerailer

words.def: A device installed in a classification yard used to reduce the speed of freight cars as they are sorted into consists[199]
words.name: Retarder

words.def: The handle that controls the directional control on a locomotive. See also Cut off.
words.name: Reverser or reverser handle

words.def: Continuously welded rail[195]
words.name: Ribbon rail

words.def: A failure in a signalling or other safety critical system which leaves the system in a safe condition[200]
words.name: Right-side failure

words.def: A highway trailer, or semi-trailer, that is specially equipped for direct use on a railroad
words.name: Roadrailer

words.def:
In UK parlance, any railway vehicle that is not capable of moving under its own power[201]
In US parlance, any railroad car or locomotive[195][202][203]
words.name: Rolling stock

words.def: See Trainee.
words.name: Rookie

words.def: Short for rotary snowplow, an extreme-duty railroad snowplow used mainly in the mountain ranges of the American West[204]
words.name: Rotary

words.def: A circular or semi-circular structure used for storage and running maintenance of locomotives
words.name: Roundhouse

words.def: A box or panel adjacent to a rail line at an interlocking, with several buttons for train operators to select a desired route, which is then either communicated to a signal tower where an operator fulfills the request, or switched automatically[205][206]
words.name: Route selector panel, punch box, or train-identification pushbuttons (New York City Subway)

words.def: The longest or steepest grade on a division, thus setting the standard for track speeds, locomotive tonnage ratings, and train handling instructions[207]
words.name: Ruling gradient

words.def: A heavy train that has lost speed control while descending a steep grade, due to either brake failure or poor preparation by the crew[208]
words.name: Runaway

words.def: An other-than-main track, typically providing access to a yard or industry and governed by the requirements of restricted speed[209]
words.name: Running track

words.def: The practice of detaching a locomotive from its train, driving it to the other end of the train and re-attaching it, to allow the train to proceed in the direction it has just come from (e.g. when it reaches its destination and forms a service in the other direction).[195][210]
words.name: Run-round

words.def: Locomotives that remain attached to a manifest or unit train from their home rails over the tracks of a receiving railroad until the train reaches its final destination[211]
words.name: Run-through power

words.def: A tank locomotive with the water tank mounted on top of the boiler like a saddle[212]
words.name: Saddle tank

words.def: The system of rules and equipment designed to ensure the safe operation of trains[213]
words.name: Safeworking

words.def: A granular material sprayed onto the rail just in front of the drive wheels to improve traction
words.name: Sand

words.def: A container on locomotives and self-propelled multiple units, or trams, that run on tramways and adhesion railways. The container holds sand which can be dropped onto the rail to improve rail adhesion under wet, steep, or slippery rail conditions. The sandbox and operating mechanism are collectively known as sanding gear.
words.name: Sandbox

words.def: Consists of a mixture of sand, aluminium, and a unique type of adhesive, used instead of plain sand for extreme slippery rail conditions
words.name: Sandite

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-10-2 wheel arrangement, named for the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway—the first railroad to use such a configuration[214][215]
words.name: Santa Fe type

words.def: A steam locomotive not equipped with a superheater; the steam thus remains at the same temperature as the water in the boiler[citation needed]
words.name: Saturated locomotive

words.def: Solid debris distilled from boiling water in a steam locomotive. To prevent corrosion damage from scale build-up, the locomotive must undergo a boiler wash once each operating month.[216]
words.name: Scale

words.def: A specialized type of freight car for extra heavy and over sized loads where the car is loaded in such a way that the load forms part of the car superstructure
words.name: Schnabel car

words.def: A signal with a single light source usually capable of displaying three different colors. An internal mechanism governs the color displayed.[212]
words.name: Searchlight

words.def: A division of track for tracking occupation[citation needed]
words.name: Section

words.def: A type of signal that has a moving arm to change the indication
words.name: Semaphore signal

words.def: A type of geared steam locomotive built to the patents of Ephraim Shay[212]
words.name: Shay locomotive

words.def: In UK and Australian parlance, to make up and divide trains in sidings, to move trains to or from sidings, or to move trains between platforms in a station[217]
words.name: Shunt

words.def: A train, usually a passenger service, that runs back and forth, usually over a relatively short distance, such as between a junction station and a branch-line terminus.
words.name: Shuttle train

words.def: A tank locomotive with water tanks mounted each side of the boiler
words.name: Side tank

words.def: A section of track off the main line. Sidings are often used for storing rolling stock or freight. A siding is also used as a form of rail access for warehouses and other businesses, where the siding will often meet up with loading docks at rail car height in the building. In the U.S. the term is also used to cover the British term: loop. Also, a passing track in the U.S.
words.name: Siding

words.def: A device that indicates the condition of the line ahead to the driver of a train
words.name: Signal

words.def: The information conveyed to a railroad vehicle operator by a block signal. Signals may use colored lights, position-significant lights or mechanical semaphores to generate various aspects.[citation needed]
words.name: Signal aspect

words.def: A building or room which houses signal levers (usually in a frame), a control panel or a VDU-based control system
words.name: Signal box

words.def: An event in which a train passes a signal to stop without authorization to do so[citation needed]
words.name: Signal passed at danger

words.def: A person in charge of the signalling at a station or junction, often in a signal box
words.name: Signalman

words.def: The narrow corridor between a pair of closely spaced tracks, nominally six feet wide. See also four-foot and ten-foot.[218]
words.name: Six-foot

words.def: The condition of fallen leaves or other debris lying on and clinging to a railroad track that could cause train wheel slippage, resulting in premature wheel wear and train delays
words.name: Slippery rail

words.def: A local speed restriction below the track's normal speed limit often designated by yellow and green flags. Slow orders can be imposed on a temporary basis to protect, for example, maintenance of way employees while sections of track are under repair. Widely used in areas where track is substandard and in need of repair.
words.name: Slow order

words.def: A locomotive that contains traction motors yet lacks the diesel engine to create its own power, which is instead supplied by a connected mother locomotive[212]
words.name: Slug

words.def: An enclosed (normally cylindrical) space attached to the end of the boiler opposite the firebox on a steam locomotive (normally the front). Supports the stack/chimney; steam pipes to and from the cylinders pass through here; contains the blastpipe/exhaust nozzle where the exhaust steam is used to provide draft for the fire. In superheated locomotives, also contains the superheater header and (optionally) a front-end throttle. A smokebox door allows access for cleaning.
words.name: Smokebox

words.def: A rail service vehicle used for snow removal from train tracks[219]
words.name: Snowplow, snow plow, snowplough, or snow plough

words.def: A long shelter erected over a railroad track on the side of a mountain to protect the line from avalanches and drifting[220]
words.name: Snow shed

words.def: The beam between two bogies
words.name: Span bolster

words.def: A bolt, pin, or nail used to hold rails, or plates connected to the rails (known as tie plates), to sleepers (ties)
words.name: Spike

words.def: See Track transition curve. Also known as tangent lead-in.[212]
words.name: Spiral easement

words.def: Maintenance of way equipment designed to spread or shape ballast profiles, remove snow, clean and dig ditches as well as trim embankments
words.name: Spreader

words.def: A self-propelled rail-defect detector car[221]
words.name: Self-propelled ultrasonic rail testing (SPURT) (India)

words.def: A method of safeworking involving a token[when defined as?][212]
words.name: Staff and ticket

words.def: A gauge where the rails are spaced 1,435 mm (4 ft 8 1⁄2 in) apart—by far the most common gauge worldwide[212]
words.name: Standard gauge

words.def: The person in charge of a station
words.name: Station master

words.def: A device generally used in passenger trains to create steam for heating. The steam generator is usually in the locomotive but may also be located in other cars.[212]
words.name: Steam generator

words.def: A reversing gear worked by a steam cylinder controlled from the cab
words.name: Steam reverser

words.def: A person in a dining car with a role similar to that of a Maitre d’Hotel[citation needed]
words.name: Steward

words.def: Pulling against train brakes at the lower end of a locomotive's power output (e.g. notches one through four) of a conventional throttle, thus keeping coupler slack stretched and permitting smoother train handling. This is considered most effective on undulating track profiles or when dynamic braking is not available.[citation needed]
words.name: Stretch braking

words.def: The trackage area within a division covered by a single timetable[222]
words.name: Subdivision

words.def: A mechanical device that boosts the pressure of engine intake air to above atmospheric level, causing an increase in power. Not to be confused with the blower used to scavenge the cylinders of a naturally aspirated two-stroke Diesel engine.
words.name: Supercharger

words.def: A device in a steam locomotive that raises the temperature of saturated steam substantially beyond the boiling point of water, increasing power and efficiency[212]
words.name: Superheater

words.def: To determine the position of constructed objects, including rail infrastructure, in relation to the earth's surface. This is accomplished by measuring angles and distances based on the principles of triangulation.
words.name: Survey

words.def: A person assigned to perform survey work
words.name: Surveyor

words.def: A railroad worker responsible for assembling trains and switching railroad cars in a yard
words.name: Switchman

words.def: Generally, a locomotive used in track maintenance and equipped with track lifting facilities, and paddles enabling ballast to be pushed beneath a rail track so as to assure its level and cant
words.name: Tamping machine

words.def: A type of rolling stock designed to transport liquid and gaseous commodities
words.name: Tank car

words.def: A spur or siding for loading freight, often used by firms not having their own direct rail access[223]
words.name: Team track

words.def: A specialized rail car attached to a steam locomotive to carry its fuel and water supplies, along with tools and flagging equipment
words.name: Tender

words.def: An area, usually at least ten feet wide, between a pair of widely spaced tracks, wide enough to form a place of safety in which railway workers can stand while a train goes past. See also four-foot and six-foot.[224]
words.name: Ten-foot

words.def: A company in the United States that owns no cars of its own and transports only the railroad cars of other companies around a specific terminal station[225]
words.name: Terminal railroad (or terminal railway)

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-10-4 wheel arrangement[citation needed]
words.name: Texas type

words.def: An electrified rail that runs along the tracks, giving power to trains. Used mostly in subways and rapid transit systems.[223]
words.name: Third rail

words.def: A passenger coach that is disconnected from one train and attached to another before continuing on with its journey, thus avoiding the need for passengers themselves to switch trains[226]
words.name: Through coach

words.def: The standard platform and track arrangement at a station. The train pulls alongside the platform, arriving from one end of the station, and may pass out the other end of the station by continuing along the same track[227]
words.name: Through platform

words.def: Combining two or more different railways onto a common length of track. This is often done to eliminate redundant trackage or improve service.[citation needed]
words.name: Through routing

words.def: A plate which is bolted to sleepers, holding the rails in place
words.name: Tie plate

words.def: The general compass direction of a railroad or subdivision, as specified by its official timetable rulebook. Only the four cardinal compass points may be used to state a train's direction of travel.[citation needed]
words.name: Timetable direction

words.def: Intermodal freight transport[223]
words.name: Trailer on flat car (TOFC)

words.def: A physical object given to a locomotive driver to authorize use of a particular stretch of single track
words.name: Token

words.def: The foundation of rail tracks
words.name: Track bed or trackbed

words.def: A form used by railroad employees that shows the locations of slow orders, maintenance of way work locations, and other conditions affecting the track and movement of trains[citation needed]
words.name: Track bulletin

words.def: An electrical circuit that detects the presence of locomotives or cars (as their wheelsets electrically bond the rails) in a block of track, and provides real-time input to signaling logic
words.name: Track circuit

words.def: The gradual application of superelevation and tighter curve radius, calculated with reference to the anticipated line speed and the final curve radius, on the approach to a bend. Also known as the transition spiral and spiral easement.
words.name: Track transition curve

words.def: See Wayobjects.
words.name: Trackside objects

words.def: A large electric motor that powers the driving wheels of an electric or diesel-electric locomotive[223]
words.name: Traction motor

words.def: The electric source for the traction motors of electric trains[citation needed]
words.name: Traction supply

words.def: The pulling or pushing force exerted by a locomotive or other vehicle
words.name: Tractive effort

words.def: A turnout is trailing if the two legs of that turnout merge in the direction of travel. See Facing.
words.name: Trailing

words.def: An employee assigned to train service, such as a conductor, brakeman, or switchman
words.name: Trainman

words.def: A dispatcher—the person in charge of all traffic within assigned blocks[citation needed]
words.name: Trainmaster

words.def: A group of rolling stock that is permanently or semi-permanently coupled together to form a unified set of equipment. Trainsets are most often used in passenger train configurations.[citation needed]
words.name: Trainset

words.def: A city-based rail system that typically shares its operational space with other vehicles and often runs on, across, or down the center of city streets
words.name: Tram

words.def: Trams that are designed to run both on the tracks of a city-based rail system and on the existing railway networks. Tram-trains' dual-voltage capability makes it possible to operate at lower speeds on city streets and at over 60 miles per hour (97 km/h) on main line tracks allowing travel in an extended geographical area without changing the method of transport.
words.name: Tram-train

words.def: A mechanical or electrical device for detecting the presence of a rail vehicle with pin-point accuracy, unlike a track circuit, which provides detection over an arbitrary distances
words.name: Treadle

words.def: A switch[citation needed]
words.name: Turnout or points

words.def: A section of track that can rotate, allowing locomotives and rolling stock to be reversed, and also allow a large number of engine maintenance sidings to be accessed in a small area
words.name: Turntable

words.def: A train in which all cars (wagons) carry the same commodity and are shipped from the same origin to the same destination, without being split up or stored en route[228]
words.name: Unit train

words.def: A continuous train brake which is fail-safe in operation; the brake is powered by a vacuum from the locomotive but the application is actually by atmospheric pressure when the vacuum is released. Now largely superseded by the air brake.
words.name: Vacuum brake

words.def: The linkage mechanism that operates the valve for a driving cylinder, to alternately admit steam to the cylinder and then exhaust it when the piston's stroke is nearly complete[229]
words.name: Valve gear

words.def: A device used for delivering a large volume of water into the tank or tender of a steam locomotive
words.name: Standpipe

words.def: A device showing the level of water in the boiler[230]
words.name: Water gauge or water glass

words.def: An alternate term for a caboose used by the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, Chicago and North Western Railway, and Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway[230]
words.name: Way car

words.def: See Local train.
words.name: Way freight

words.def: Trackside objects or any structures at the wayside or beside the rail tracks usually within the right-of-way, such as railway signals, third rails, overhead lines and their supports, electrification systems, platforms, or boom barriers[citation needed]
words.name: Wayobjects or wayside objects

words.def: Trackside[citation needed]
words.name: Wayside

words.def: A type of tank locomotive. The water tank is mounted between the frame plates, beneath the cab and boiler.
words.name: Well tank

words.def: A flat wagon with a depressed centre used for carrying extra tall loads
words.name: Well wagon (UIC)

words.def: The rolling component typically pressed onto an axle and mounted on a rail car or locomotive truck or bogie. Wheels are cast or forged (wrought) and are heat treated to have a specific hardness. New wheels are trued to a specific profile before being pressed onto an axle. All wheel profiles need to be periodically monitored to insure proper wheel to rail interface. Improperly trued wheels increase rolling resistance, reduce energy efficiency and may create unsafe operation. A railroad wheel typically consists of two main parts: the wheel itself, and the tire around the outside. A railway tire is itself steel, and is typically heated and pressed onto the wheel, where it remains firmly as it shrinks and cools.
words.name: Wheel

words.def: The process of a wheel climbing up and often off the inside or gauge side of the rail. It is a major source of derailments. Wheel climb is more likely to occur in curves with wheels whose flanges are worn or have improper angles. See Rail adhesion.
words.name: Wheel climb

words.def: The inner section of a wheel that rides between the two rails. The angle between the wheel tread and flange is often specific to the rail to prevent wheel climb and possible derailments. See Rail adhesion. The wheel flange is part of the wheel tire.
words.name: Wheel flange

words.def: The on-contact interaction between wheels and rails. The term is used in connection with the design and management of their interaction.
words.name: Wheel-rail interface

words.def: The loss of traction due to a slippery rail or wheel. Wheel slip was common with steam engines as they started to move due to the excessive torque often generated at low speed. Steam engines carried sand dispensing gear to increase traction at the start of motion.[230]
words.name: Wheel slip

words.def: An historical railway occupation; people employed to tap train wheels with hammers and listen to the sound made to determine the integrity of the wheel; cracked wheels, like cracked bells, do not sound the same as their intact counterparts. The job was associated with the steam age, but they still operate in some eastern European countries. Modern planned maintenance procedures have mostly obviated the need for the wheel-tapper.
words.name: Wheeltapper

words.def: The slightly conical section (often with a 1 in 20 slope) of a railroad wheel that is the primary contact point with the rail. See Rail adhesion.
words.name: Wheel tread

words.def: Train whistles are used as a safety warning and also by the engineer to communicate to other railroad workers. See train whistle for a description of the whistle code used to communicate. Also a nickname for an air horn on a diesel locomotive. Steam engine whistles were historically known as chimes in the US during the 19th century.
words.name: Whistle

words.def: An advance warning to the engineer of an upcoming grade crossing. It is the point at which the engineer should begin sounding the whistle or horn.
words.name: Whistle post

words.def: A system of describing steam locomotive wheel arrangements (e.g. 4-6-4, 2-10-2). The first number indicates the number of "pilot" wheels that help lead the engine into turns. The second is the number of coupled wheels ("drivers"). Third are the trailing idler wheels, usually to provide support to larger fireboxes. Articulated locomotives are similarly described. For example, a Union Pacific "Big Boy" would be described as a 4-8-8-4, wherein the pilot has four wheels, followed by two sets of drivers, eight wheels per set, and a four-wheel trailing bogie under the firebox. The numbers include the wheels on both sides of the engine, so a 2-8-2 engine would have one idler, four drivers, and a final idler on each side of the engine.
words.name: Whyte notation

words.def: A largely superseded Level or Grade Crossing Warning Signal consisting of a swinging disc facing road traffic with a red light in the centre. The disc normally hangs straight down, but an approaching train will set it swinging from side to side, the red light will illuminate or flash, and a bell will ring.
words.name: Wigwag

words.def: The condition of a steam locomotive drawing water through its throttle valve, cylinders, and smokestack, often causing damage to the cylinders or running gear[citation needed]
words.name: Working water, foaming, or priming

words.def: A failure in a signalling system that leaves the system in a dangerous condition[citation needed]
words.name: Wrong-side failure

words.def: A location where rolling stock is switched to and from trains, freight is loaded or unloaded, and consists made up[231]
words.name: Yard

words.def: The person responsible for conducting all traffic within the yard in order to assemble or disassemble consists[citation needed]
words.name: Yardmaster

words.def: A colour associated with a warning or a need to slow down when used by flags or signals, but the exact meaning varies from railway to railway
words.name: Yellow

words.def: A steam locomotive with a 2-8-8-4 wheel arrangement[citation needed]
words.name: Yellowstone type

words.def: A method of climbing and descending steep gradients, where shallow-gradient track reverses direction for a while, and then reverses again to continue in the original direction
words.name: Zig zag or switchback
